importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article reports on ongoing redistricting efforts in Missouri and the timeline for a potential referendum on the new congressional map, which is set to occur in 2026 if the required signature threshold is met.
This is the deadline for collecting 106,000 signatures to qualify the referendum for the ballot in 2026, making it a critical deadline for the People Not Politicians Missouri campaign.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline spans the period from the creation of Missouri's gerrymandered congressional map in late 2025 through a 2026 referendum, allowing voters to decide the map's legitimacy.

keyTakeAways: Missouri's Republican-led legislature passed a gerrymandered congressional map in late 2025, targeting Democratic Rep. Emanuel Cleaver II's seat in Kansas City.
A grassroots effort led by People Not Politicians Missouri has gathered over 100,000 signatures to hold a 2026 referendum on the map, arguing that redistricting undermines fair representation.

The state's Attorney General Catherine Hanaway and Secretary of State Denny Hoskins have challenged the referendum, claiming it violates constitutional law or process, but the group maintains legal standing under the state constitution.
Several Republicans, including Michael Davis and Bill Allen, support the new map, while 15 Republicans—including speaker Jon Patterson—oppose it, especially in areas directly affected.
Progressive candidate Rebeca Amezcua-Hogan opposes the map, arguing it will dilute her voting power and worsen existing challenges like affordable housing and mental health access in Kansas City.
The Democratic National Committee has pledged support, providing staff and funding to the effort.
The group believes Missouri is being used as a test case by the GOP to implement redistricting without public input, especially in a state with historically lower political engagement.

namedEntities.name: Leann Villaluz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Organizer and volunteer leader for People Not Politicians Missouri
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a primary figure in the grassroots effort to gather signatures for a referendum on Missouri's redistricting map.

namedEntities.name: People Not Politicians Missouri
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Grassroots campaign group opposing Missouri's gerrymandered congressional map
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group is central to the article's narrative, leading the signature-gathering campaign for a 2026 voter referendum.

namedEntities.name: Mike Kehoe
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He signed the new gerrymandered congressional map into law, making him a key political figure in the redistricting controversy.

namedEntities.name: Catherine Hanaway
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She filed a lawsuit claiming the referendum violates both U.S. and Missouri constitutions, challenging the legal basis of public redistricting votes.

namedEntities.name: Denny Hoskins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He initially rejected the referendum petition but later approved it, while claiming earlier signatures are invalid, creating legal and political controversy.

namedEntities.name: Rebeca Amezcua-Hogan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Progressive candidate running for Kansas City Council
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a plaintiff in a lawsuit challenging the redistricting and personally opposes the map, citing concerns about diluted voting power and resource allocation.

namedEntities.name: Emanuel Cleaver II
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Longtime Democratic U.S. Representative from Kansas City, Missouri
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His seat is specifically targeted in the new gerrymandered map, making him a focal point of the opposition effort.

namedEntities.name: Michael Davis
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican state legislator and member of the Freedom Caucus
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He championed the new map and believes it sends a conservative message to Washington, D.C. to maintain Republican control of the House.

namedEntities.name: Bill Allen
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican state representative from Kansas City's northland
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He opposes mid-decade redistricting, arguing that representatives must serve their districts, not the party or national agenda.

namedEntities.name: Jon Patterson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Speaker of the Missouri House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is one of the 15 Republicans who voted against the new map, highlighting internal GOP division on redistricting.

namedEntities.name: Democratic National Committee (DNC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: National political organization of the Democratic Party
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The DNC has supported the People Not Politicians Missouri campaign by contributing staff and financial resources.

namedEntities.name: President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His 2024 redistricting initiative prompted a nationwide political battle over redistricting, influencing Missouri's action and the broader GOP strategy.

namedEntities.name: Kansas City
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the central location of the redistricting dispute, where districts are being split and where the grassroots campaign is most active.

namedEntities.name: Chappell Roan concert
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It served as a public platform where Leann Villaluz collected signatures, illustrating efforts to engage diverse communities.

namedEntities.name: U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Missouri's new map aims to shift control of this body in the 2026 midterms, prompting national political attention and opposition.

namedEntities.name: Missouri Legislature
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It passed the new congressional map during a special session, demonstrating state-level political action on redistricting.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Missouri's newly gerrymandered congressional map, passed by a Republican-dominated legislature and signed into law by Governor Mike Kehoe, is under legal and public challenge. The map targets the seat of long-serving Democratic Representative Emanuel Cleaver II in Kansas City. In response, the grassroots group People Not Politicians Missouri, led by Leann Villaluz, has mobilized over 100,000 residents to collect signatures for a 2026 referendum that would allow voters to decide whether to keep or reject the map. The campaign is met with resistance from state officials, including Attorney General Catherine Hanaway and Secretary of State Denny Hoskins, who argue the process violates constitutional law. Internal divisions exist within the Republican Party, with 15 lawmakers, including Speaker Jon Patterson and representative Bill Allen, opposing the map due to concerns over district representation. Progressive candidate Rebeca Amezcua-Hogan, who is running for Kansas City Council, also opposes the map, citing concerns about diluted voting power and worsening local challenges. The Democratic National Committee has joined the effort, providing support. The article underscores growing public resistance to mid-decade redistricting, especially in states like Missouri that are seen as political test cases for GOP gerrymandering tactics.
title: These voters want to overturn Missouri's new gerrymandered congressional map
